title: His Dark Materials episode 1 review: James McAvoy leads enchanting cast
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

His Dark Materials is one of the most anticipated adaptations of the entire year – and following the 2007 film attempt falling show, BBC and HBO certainly had the pressure on them to deliver.

Thankfully, the first episode of the series sets up a story that is worth the time and money put into it, creating something that is a perfect watch on Sunday nights as autumn nights turn into chilly winters.

Bringing in an all-star cast, Phillip Pullman’s Dark Materials fully comes to life with the introduction to the world (that is both like an unlike our own) in full glory, creating a spectacle worthy of the cinema, let alone your HD TV on your living room wall.

The first episode, Roger, is enough to keep us interested as it does the vital job of setting up the world that they want us to invest in, so instead of focusing on the action does more to foreshadow what’s to come.

We meet Lyra (the incredible Dafne Keen) whose attachment to her somewhat cold and aloof uncle Lord Asriel (James McAvoy) only fuels her desire to be an explorer just like him, but as a young girl is currently confined to the walls of a university in Oxford.

In a world where she’s going through the age of ‘not a young girl, but yet an adult’, she’s accompanied at all times by her daemon Pantalaimon, a creature all humans have that personifies their soul and follows them throughout their lives, and her best friend, servant Roger.

In the uni grounds, she’s under the watchful eyes of adults who have been trusted to take care of her, but it soon becomes apparent that they might not be as reliable as first assumed.

Meanwhile, outside the protective walls that Lyra has grown up in, there are a group of travelling humans called the Gyptians, who are living in a completely different way of life as they move through the rivers of Oxford in their own unique way.

Dafne Keen is the perfect adventure-seeking Lyra (Picture: BBC)

The entire country is ruled over by a secretive government known as the Magisterium, who have more overarching power than they’re willing to admit, or willing to give up.

When Lyra meets the mysterious Miss Coulter (Ruth Wilson) she begins to see a way into the life she’s always dreamed of leading.

But soon Lyra’s nosey nature and ability to explore sets her on a path to a bigger world, and it becomes clear that she may be the key to a prophecy that could change their world (that is both like and unlike ours) forever.

We’ve promised to keep this review spoiler-free so what we will say is this: His Dark Materials is literally built for Sunday night telly with the family, and delves into a fantasy world that will quench the thirst of fantasy lovers both adults and children alike.

The creatures that follow the humans are a pure spectacle to watch, made all the more magical by the revelation that for the most part, they’re puppets. So the grand tiger (voiced by Helen McCrory) that keeps faithful to Asriel is actually there, and absolutely stunning.

The world as everyone knows it is about to change forever (Picture: BBC)

Meanwhile, James McAvoy as the somewhat embittered man with a plan is a complicated character you can’t help but dislike but want to know more about. His fight for the discovery of a mysterious substance called Dust is enough to bring the intrigue while also making his behaviour towards an ever-doting Lyra a little heartbreaking.

First coming to prominence in Wolverine’s final bow Logan, Dafne Keen is a force to be reckoned with for such a young actress, and her headstrong nature as Lyra makes her an instant heroine for young children to emulate and look up to as she heads off into a new world.

Advertisement

His Dark Materials is a magical mystery world that we haven’t seen before in such intricate detail since the Harry Potter franchise (though Lord knows people have tried) – and that’s in part down to the special effects that keeps manages to balance the real world we know to the false one created for the series.

It’s both old and new realities, with blimps instead of planes and technology almost entire absent, but a modern sensibility running through the characters.

The story also does the important thing of making it feel adult enough to neither bore parents nor talk down to kids who could watch it.

Fans of the original books will not be disappointed, with a faithful recreation we’ve been looking to see since we were first brought into the world back in 1995.

We have high hopes for the eight-episode series (and the second that is already in production) that will sail us through to the end of the year in style.

His Dark Materials starts Sunday 3 November on BBC One.
